title: Who does the GDPR apply to and where?
displayTitle: Who does the GDPR apply to and where?
body:
The GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the European Economic Area (EEA), regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EEA or not.

The EEA consists the EU member states plus the 3 members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) – Norway, Iceland and Lichtenstein

This means that all FCDO staff in the UK and at posts must apply the GDPR, regardless of the location of post or nationality of the person whose data they are dealing with.

Processing personal data covers the following, irrespective of how the data is collected: collection, recording, organisation, structuring, storage, adaptation or alteration, retrieval, consultation, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available, alignment or combination, restriction, erasure or destruction.

title: Introduction to the General Data Protection Regulation
body:
This module gives an overview of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the key differences from the existing data protection regulations. After completion, you should able to work more confidently with the requirements of the GDPR.

This module explains:

  • Who the GDPR applies to and where

title: Introduction
body:
The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) came into force on 25 May 2018.

The GDPR is broadly similar to the current data protection legislation; many of the principles and terminology are the same. However, there are some key differences and the GDPR is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. The FCDO must report any such data breaches and those affected, to the ICO within 72 hours of becoming aware of them. We must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether we are required to notify.

body: Which individuals does the GDPR apply to?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

The GDPR will also apply to the processing of personal data in the EU by an organisation not established in the EU, where the activities relate to either:

  1. Offering goods or services within EU (irrespective of whether payment is required)
  2. Monitoring of individuals behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the EU

This means that even if a company has no physical base in the EU, the GDPR may still apply if goods and services are offered to those located within the EU.

On this basis you do not need to be an EU citizen for the GDPR to apply. Anyone located in the EU interacting with services offered in the EU is in scope of the GDPR.

title: What personal data does the GDPR cover?
displayTitle: What personal data does the GDPR cover?
body: There are four different types of personal data that are in scope of the GDPR.
instruction: Explore each of these in more detail below.

_items.body:
Under the GDPR personal data means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person. This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

Examples: name, email address, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

However data of these types might not always be personally identifiable. For example the name John Smith is very common, however when combined with other data, such as date of birth and address this then becomes identifiable. Remember that names are not needed to identify someone - you probably don't know the names of all your neighbours but you can identify them.
_items.title: Personal data

title: Who needs to apply the GDPR?
displayTitle: Who needs to apply the GDPR?
body:
All FCDO staff must apply the GDPR globally when processing any personal data (eg staff information and that of external/customers) - wherever you are based or whatever the nationality of the individual whose data you are processing.

Even if you are in a department or post that does not process large amounts of personal data, it is likely that at some point you will handle personal data – such as receiving appraisals as a member of a hiring panel or compiling a guest list/sending out invitations for an event.

title: GDPR by default
body: Which of the following are legal requirements under the GDPR?

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

‘Privacy by design’ is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider individuals’ privacy from the start of the design of any system or service rather than being bolted on at the end. 

The GDPR also introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority.

The GDPR requires the appointment a data protection officer (DPO) if you are a public authority, or if you carry out certain types of processing activities involving large scales of personal data or special categories of personal data.

The GDPR requires personal data to be processed in a manner that ensures its security. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

title: What is the GDPR and why is it needed?
displayTitle: What is the GDPR and why is it needed?
body: The world we live in today is vastly different from that of 1995 when data protection laws in the European Union were last updated (1998 in the case of the Data Protection Act in the UK). The GDPR is a new regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

title: Establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data
body:
The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner. There are six lawful bases outlined in the GDPR. At least one must apply. Without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of consent, if you could reasonably perform your tasks without collecting personal data then the lawful basis does not apply. If you could provide the same service without collecting personal data, but still want to collect that data, you have to get consent from the individual.

_items.title: Public task
_items.body:
You can process personal data if it is necessary for you to perform a task in the public interest or for your official functions, where the task or function has a clear basis in law.

Most of what that FCDO does falls under this legal basis. But we should be careful not to make it our default without considering the other bases first and whether additional ones also apply.

FCDO examples:

Conferences and events

Personal data on those attending including name, address, dietary requirements

Consular Assistance

Personal data on those receiving assistance, including name, date of birth, address, passport number, next of kin, nature of case and record of assistance provided (which may also include information from third parties such as police).

Prism and Vault

Stores personnel data of FCDO staff and secondees: HR data, Payroll data, Contract data, Customer financial data.

_items.title: Performance of contract
_items.body:
You can process personal data if you need to fulfil a contract you have with the individual, or if they have asked you to take specific steps before entering into a contract.

For example, you can process personal data to provide a quote for fitting double glazing on a house and the subsequent fitting.

There are few, if any acts of processing in the FCDO that would result in this legal basis being preferred over public task.

_items.title: Legal obligation
_items.body:
You can process personal data if you need to in order to comply with UK law. For example, if the FCDO needs to process personal data to comply with UK employment law. Contractual obligations you have with third parties do not count as a legal basis for processing. 

If you are processing personal data on the basis of a legal obligation, the individual has no right to data portability, or right to object (see Individuals’ rights section further on). An individual has a right to erasure if the legal obligation has expired. For example, if someone left a company over 3 years ago then there is unlikely to be a legal obligation for the employer to keep hold of data about that person (a very small quantity is required for longer). 

FCDO examples:

Income information for tax purposes

The FCDO is required to pass information to HMRC about the taxable income we have paid to staff and deductions we have made for tax and national insurance. We are also required to provide other data such as your home address to assist HMRC’s work.

Retention of certain staff records

Under the rules of the Principal Civil Service Pension Scheme we are required to keep records of service history and pensionable salary and allowances until the employee concerned is 100 or until death in case of any queries about their pension entitlements.  

Freedom of Information requests

The FCDO is legally obliged to respond to requests for information. We have names and contact details of requesters to enable us to communicate with them. We are also required to ask for certain further personal details to verify the identities of those making Subject Access Requests.

_items.title: Vital interests
_items.body:
You can process personal data if it is necessary to protect someone’s life. This does not apply if you can reasonably protect the person’s vital interests in another less intrusive way.

This lawful basis also does not apply for health data or other special category data if the individual is capable of giving consent.

FCDO example:

Crisis response
Collection and use of personal data when we need to evacuate people quickly, such as natural disasters/emergencies, outbreak of an epidemic/pandemic etc.

_items.title: Legitimate interests
_items.body:
You can process personal data if doing so is in the legitimate interests of the individual, third parties, or society. Legitimate interests is the most flexible lawful basis for processing, but you cannot assume it will always be the most appropriate. 

There are few, if any acts of processing in the FCDO that would result in this legal basis being preferred over public task.

_items.title: Consent
_items.body:
Under GDPR, individuals must be informed about how personal data is going to be used and consent given for each use. You cannot ask for open-ended consent to use data however you want to. 

A good example comes when performing a medical procedure on a patient. In this case, consent must granted in full knowledge of the possible consequences. This is a practice known as 'informed consent'. 

Gaining consent must be through clear affirmative action, such as a button press or an opt-in tick box. Hidden conditions and opt-out options where no action is required does not constitute clearly obtained consent under GDPR.

Additionally the individual must be able to withdraw his or her consent at any time. The process for withdrawing consent must be as easy to complete as that for giving consent.

FCDO example:

Consular Assistance Casework Data 

The Consular Customer Insight Team use data collected by various methods, to be passed to their partner research agency (IFF Research) for purposes of contacting the customer for feedback. Where data has been collected by online methods (Emergency Travel Documents, Legalisation and CABS) this data is retained as a result of active consent.

_items.title: Data Protection Officer
_items.body:
The GDPR requires public authorities to appointment a Data Protection Officer (DPO).  The FCDO’s DPO operates independently of our internal hierarchy and reports to the PUS. 

DPOs monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations, provide advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) and act as a contact point for the organisation both internally and externally.
Data controller means a person who (either alone or jointly or in common with other persons) determines the purposes for which and the manner in which any personal data are, or are to be processed.
_items.title: Data Controller

_items.body: Data processor, in relation to personal data, means any person (other than an employee of the data controller) who processes the data on behalf of the data controller.
_items.title: Data Processor

title: Individual rights
body: One of the main changes brought in by the GDPR is the addition or enhancement of a number of individual rights. These rights are particularly relevant if the lawful basis for processing personal data is either through consent or contract.

_items.body:
Individuals have the right to be informed about how personal data about them is collected and used. This is a key transparency requirement under the GDPR.

This information should be presented in a privacy notice (see section further on). This should be presented to the individual when data is collected, in clear, concise language and be easily accessible.
_items.title: Right to be informed
Right to access (subject access requests)
_items.body:
The GDPR gives people the right to ask the FCDO whether or not personal data about them is being processed, in what territory and for what purpose.

This right to access exists in the present Data Protection Act (DPA) and the FCDO does not charge for this. Under GDPR, the FCDO must provide a copy of the personal data within a month of the request and in an electronic format where possible.

_items.title: Right to rectification
_items.body: Individuals have the right to have personal data corrected if it is inaccurate or incomplete. Where necessary, the FCDO must also correct any copies shared with others.

The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles an individual to direct the controller to erase personal data about them, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially  halt processing of the data by third parties.

Data must be erased if:

  • it is no longer relevant to the original purpose for processing
  • no lawful basis exists for the data to be held and processed
  • an individual withdraws consent

This right does NOT apply to individuals whose data has been processed to carry out government functions (public task).
_items.title: Right to be forgotten

_items.body:
Individuals have a right to ‘block’ or suppress processing of personal data.

Such rights can be exercised when:

  • the accuracy of the personal data is contested
  • where the individual has objected to the processing (only in the case of performance of a public task or legitimate interest)
  • the processing is unlawful
  • the data is needed for future reference but should no longer be processed
_items.title: Right to restrict processing
Right to data portability
_items.body:
The GDPR introduces a new data portability right – the right for an individual to receive personal data they have provided to the FCDO or that has been gathered automatically by us. This must be provided in a commonly-used and machine readable format. Additionally the individual has the right to request that the data is transmitted directly to another organisation.

The "improving data quality" module (available in GLO as part of the FCDO data skills course) contains further information on providing data in the correct format.

If the lawful basis for processing is based on having consent, the individual has the right to withdraw that consent at any time. 

The process of withdrawing consent must be as easy as giving consent in the first place.
_items.title: Right to withdraw consent (if applicable)
Right to object
_items.body:
Individuals have the right to object to the FCDO processing data about them. The right to object is not an absolute right and it applies only in certain circumstances. If one of these circumstances is met, you must stop processing data about them. The valid circumstances are:

  • when personal data is used for direct marketing (in this case the right is absolute as a data subject can object at any time)
  • when data is used for research or statistical purposes, unless the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest (e.g. in health research)
  • the data is processed based on public or legitimate interests

If you wish to continue processing you will need to demonstrate you have compelling legitimate interest that overrides the individual’s rights and freedoms.

Individuals have the right to not be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling.

Automated processing can be carried out if the decision is:

  • necessary for the entry into or performance of a contract
  • authorised in law
  • based on the individual’s explicit consent

In all cases individuals must be informed about the automated processing and be able to request human intervention or challenge a decision.
_items.title: Right to not be subject solely to automated decision making

title: Privacy notices
body:
The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully and communicate this basis clearly with the individual. Privacy notices are one of the most visible aspects that demonstrate compliance with the GDPR. The FCDO’s Privacy Notice is on our .gov.uk page. The staff Privacy Notice is on the intranet.

Individuals must be informed clearly about what data is collected, exactly what it is used for and how they can exercise their rights over the data. This information must be presented to the individual as near to the point of data collection as possible. 

In addition to fines being imposed for non-compliance, they can also be imposed where a privacy notice is deemed unclear or misleading.

title: How well do you know the GDPR?
displayTitle: How well do you know the GDPR?
body: Take the quiz and test your knowledge

title: More information
body: For more details see the Information Commissioner's Office guide. You can also check additional data protection regulations in the UK’s Data Protection Act.

title: Data breaches
body:
The GDPR introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority. A personal data breach means a breach of security leading to the unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data. This includes both accidental and deliberate breaches.

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. The FCDO must report any such data breaches and those affected, to the Information Commissioner’s Office within 72 hours of becoming aware of them. We must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether we are required to notify.

Significant penalties can be imposed on organisations who breach the GDPR.

_items.body:
'Privacy by design' is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider people’s privacy from the start of the design of any system or service and not just bolt it on at the end.

Where data processing is likely to result in a high risk to individuals, a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is required under the GDPR.

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks
_items.title: Privacy by design
Contracts with data processors
_items.body:
Where the FCDO has a contract with an external supplier, the FCDO will usually be the data controller and the supplier will be the data processor (see GDPR-specific role section). This relationship will be set out in the contract. The FCDO must only contract with suppliers who can provide sufficient guarantees that the requirements of the GDPR will be met and individuals’ rights protected.

Suppliers can only process personal data on the documented instructions of the FCDO. Suppliers, however, have some direct responsibilities under the GDPR, such as having to give notification of data breaches, and being subject to fines or other sanctions if they do not comply.

The GDPR contains explicit provisions requiring you to document your processing activities (what you do with personal data). 

As well as being a legal requirement, documenting your processing activities can support good data governance and help you demonstrate your compliance with other aspects of the GDPR.

The amount of documentation required depends on the size of your organisation and the activities it carries out.

Documentation can help in many areas including:

  • establishing the extent of personal data your organisation holds
  • establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data
  • writing clearer privacy statements
  • fulfilling your obligations to share the data with others including those the data is about
  • records keeping including which territory data is stored in, records of consent and Data Protection Impact Assessment reports
  • responding to queries from your supervisory authority (eg ICO)
  • notification and management of data breaches
_items.title: Records of processing
Ensuring transfers are legitimate
_items.body:
The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EEA than before.

Transfers outside of the EEA may be made:

  • to locations that the European Commission decide provide an adequate level of protection
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is provided through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary to fulfil the lawful basis

The GDPR requires personal data to be processed securely. This includes protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

Additionally, the GDPR requires that personal data only be retained while there is a lawful basis for doing so, such as needing to have proof of a contract or employment. It might not be necessary to keep the complete record for this, rather only a part. This is a practice known as data minimisation that can also help minimise risk.
_items.title: Data retention and security

_items.body: The practice of data minimisation is about limiting personal data collection, storage, usage and retention to only the data that is relevant and absolutely necessary for carrying out the purpose for which the data is processed.
_items.title: Data minimisation

title: Privacy notices - a checklist
body:
The privacy notice should clearly outline:

  • the purpose and lawful basis of the processing
  • the name of the controller and contact details of the data protection officer
  • details of data transfers to third countries and safeguards
  • the retention period or criteria used to determine the retention period
  • the individual’s rights
  • the existence of automated decision making, including profiling and information about how decisions are made, their significance and their consequences

title: Who does the GDPR apply to and where?
displayTitle: Who does the GDPR apply to and where?
body:
The GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the European Economic Area (EEA), regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EEA or not.

The EEA consists the EU member states plus the 3 members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) – Norway, Iceland and Lichtenstein.

title: What happens at the end of the Transition Period?
displayTitle: What happens at the end of the Transition Period?
body: From 1 January 2021, the government intends to incorporate the GDPR into UK data protection law.
instruction: Click to explore the impact of data flows to and from the EU/EEA

_items.title: EU/EEA to UK data flows
_items.body:
At the end of the transition period, the UK will become a ‘third country’ for data protection purposes. The UK is seeking adequacy decisions from the EU under both the General Data Protection Regulation (covering general and commercial data flows) and Law Enforcement Directive (covering law enforcement data flows) which, if secured by the end of the transition period, will allow for the free flow of personal data from the EU/EEA to the UK to continue uninterrupted. Adequacy is an autonomous process and is not reliant on a wider negotiated outcome, but although the negotiations are making progress, the government is also preparing for a No-Adequacy decision. 

In the event that the European Commission have not recognised the UK as adequate by the end of the transition period, the transfer of personal data from​ the EU/EEA to the UK will​ be restricted unless appropriate safeguards are in place, or the transfer benefits from one of the statutory exceptions (known as derogations for specific situations). Further information on international transfers, including a list of appropriate safeguards, is available from the Information Commissioner's Office.

_items.title: UK to EU/EEA data flows
_items.body: The UK has legislated so that personal data for general processing can flow freely, on a transitional basis, from the UK to the 30 EEA States, as well as EU and EEA Institutions. This means that personal data for general processing can continue to flow freely from the UK to the EU/EEA.  ​As legally required by UK law, the government will review the ‘adequacy’ of these arrangements by 1 January 2025.
